update.description:
* Allow zprocess 2.0, which is backward compatible.

* Fixed bug in which columns no longer present in the dataframe (due to removing
    shots) were not removed from the Qt model.

    This entailed changing DataFrameModel.update_row() and EditColumns.update_columns()

    DataFrameModel.update_row() was modified to detect when the
    Qt model has columns no longer present in the dataframe (this is the part
    of the code where *new* columns are detected, as well). Defunct columns in the
    Qt model are deleted and a few dictionaries are updated to reflect the new
    numbering of columns.

    Updated the conditional emission of the signal DataFrameModel.columns_changed()
    at the end of this method. Previously only emitted when new columns were added,
    is now emitted when columns were deleted as well

    The only slot connected to this signal is FileBox.on_columns_changed(),
    which calls EditColumns.update_columns() with some of the updated dictionaries
    (EditColumns is the GUI for selecting which columns to show in the FileBox).

    EditColumns.update_columns() has therefore been modified to correctly handle
    the fact that the new dictionaries may have had columns removed, and not just
    added as was previously the case.
update.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

pull_request.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

pullrequest.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

content.raw:
We hit this bug in the Spielman RbLi lab as well (before pulling from my fork to get the fix), so it's not as rare as it first seemed.

It turns out this bug was a regression introduced by 244cf0e, which itself fixed #18.

By making lyse ignore empty dataframes when concatenating (as required by pandas ≥ 0.18), the dataframe lost its record of the current columns. This is fine now, as lyse now makes fewer assumptions about the state of columns, and happily recreates and deletes columns as necessary. It's a cleaner situation than before the regression - the situation then was just "remember any column you've ever seen forever". Now if you delete shots and add ones with entirely different columns, you'll only see columns relevant to the newer shots, instead of all the old ones full of NaNs. It's still possible to have superfluous columns full of NaNs if you add shots that lack current columns, then delete the shots that *do* have those columns. But that's not so bad - if you're loading shots together like that maybe that's what you want.

Anyway, I have added an extra commit that makes lyse remember the visibility status of columns that were deleted and then reappeared. This means that if you mark columns as hidden, then delete shots, then add shots, the same columns will be hidden and you won't have to re-hide them again. This is how it used to work before the regression, but now the code is more explicit about it rather than expecting the dataframe columns to just live forever as before.
content.html:
We hit this bug in the Spielman RbLi lab as well (before pulling from my fork to get the fix), so it's not as rare as it first seemed.

It turns out this bug was a regression introduced by 244cf0e, which itself fixed #18.

By making lyse ignore empty dataframes when concatenating (as required by pandas ≥ 0.18), the dataframe lost its record of the current columns. This is fine now, as lyse now makes fewer assumptions about the state of columns, and happily recreates and deletes columns as necessary. It's a cleaner situation than before the regression - the situation then was just "remember any column you've ever seen forever". Now if you delete shots and add ones with entirely different columns, you'll only see columns relevant to the newer shots, instead of all the old ones full of NaNs. It's still possible to have superfluous columns full of NaNs if you add shots that lack current columns, then delete the shots that do have those columns. But that's not so bad - if you're loading shots together like that maybe that's what you want.

Anyway, I have added an extra commit that makes lyse remember the visibility status of columns that were deleted and then reappeared. This means that if you mark columns as hidden, then delete shots, then add shots, the same columns will be hidden and you won't have to re-hide them again. This is how it used to work before the regression, but now the code is more explicit about it rather than expecting the dataframe columns to just live forever as before.

pull_request.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

update.description:
* Allow zprocess 2.0, which is backward compatible.

* Fixed bug in which columns no longer present in the dataframe (due to removing
    shots) were not removed from the Qt model.

    This entailed changing DataFrameModel.update_row() and EditColumns.update_columns()

    DataFrameModel.update_row() was modified to detect when the
    Qt model has columns no longer present in the dataframe (this is the part
    of the code where *new* columns are detected, as well). Defunct columns in the
    Qt model are deleted and a few dictionaries are updated to reflect the new
    numbering of columns.

    Updated the conditional emission of the signal DataFrameModel.columns_changed()
    at the end of this method. Previously only emitted when new columns were added,
    is now emitted when columns were deleted as well

    The only slot connected to this signal is FileBox.on_columns_changed(),
    which calls EditColumns.update_columns() with some of the updated dictionaries
    (EditColumns is the GUI for selecting which columns to show in the FileBox).

    EditColumns.update_columns() has therefore been modified to correctly handle
    the fact that the new dictionaries may have had columns removed, and not just
    added as was previously the case.
update.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

pull_request.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

pullrequest.title: zprocess version update, fix bug reported on mailing list

content.raw: I suspect there is still a problem where if the number of levels in the dataframe (i.e `('images', 'side', 'absorption')` is 3 levels) decreases, things will also break, as there appears to be no code to handle this. This would happen if you loaded shots with lots of levels, then deleted them, then loaded shots with fewer levels. But that's a separate issue - I've filed it as issue #19.
content.html: I suspect there is still a problem where if the number of levels in the dataframe (i.e ('images', 'side', 'absorption') is 3 levels) decreases, things will also break, as there appears to be no code to handle this. This would happen if you loaded shots with lots of levels, then deleted them, then loaded shots with fewer levels. But that's a separate issue - I've filed it as issue #19.
